title-group.article-title: High transition temperature shape memory polymer composites based on bismaleimide resin

article-meta.aff: Polymers and Special Chemicals Group, Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre (VSSC), Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala, India

author-notes.corresp: C. P. Reghunadhan Nair, Polymers and Special Chemicals Group, Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre (VSSC), Thiruvananthapuram 695 022, Kerala, India. Email: cprnair@gmail.com

abstract.p: Bismaleimide–allyl phenol polymer system exhibiting shape memory characteristics and possessing transition temperature of up to 220°C (Ttrans) was synthesized by coreacting 2,2-bis 4[(4-maleimidophenoxy)phenyl]propane (BMIP) and o,o′-diallylbisphenol A (DABA) with a bismaleimide-end-capped poly(tetramethyleneoxide) (BMI-PTMO). BMI-PTMO that served as shape memory polymer was synthesized and characterized using Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR), nuclear magnetic resonance, chemical analysis and size exclusion chromatography. The cured network containing varying proportions of poly(tetramethyleneoxide) was synthesized by varying the concentration of BMI-PTMO in the ternary blend. Cure characteristics were investigated by FTIR, differential scanning calorimetry and rheometry. Elastic memory composites were processed using carbon fabric from varying blend composition at fixed resin to reinforcement ratio. PTMO enhanced the flexibility of the network. The system as a whole possessing high transition temperature, its storage modulus decreased with increase in PTMO content. The polymer possessed good shape recovery characteristics and the recovery time decreased with increasing concentration of the shape memory component. The system showed shape recovery of 88–98% in about a minute at Ttrans. The extent of shape recovery was a direct function of PTMO concentration. The recovery time showed an inverse relationship to the modulus ratio.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Stimulus-responsive materials respond to a particular stimulus, such as heat, chemical and light. Stimulus-responsive shape memory materials (SMMs) are able to recover their original shape, after being quasi-plastically distorted.1 This shape memory effect (SME) is manifested by several materials such as alloys, polymers and ceramics.2–6 SMMs are ideal for an integrated intelligent system, in which “the material machine” can sense and then generate reactive motion as preprogrammed. Fixing the temporary shape (distorted shape) is known as programming and it is followed by the shape recovery process to complete a full cycle.

The polymers with SME properties are shape memory polymers (SMPs) that are undergoing rapid development for tailored properties and special functions.7–9 The three major categories of SMPs are thermoresponsive SMP (by means of heating), photoresponsive SMP (light with different wavelengths) and chemoresponsive SMP (chemicals induced).10–12 Shape recovery in a particular SMP may be triggered by more than one stimulus. For instance, heat, water and ethanol are all possible stimuli for polyurethanes (PUs) and their composites. Special advantages of SMPs over their metallic counterparts include high recoverable strain, easily tunable properties, etc.13–15 Almost all the polymers intrinsically have SME properties that are also thermo- and chemoresponsive.

Diverse mechanisms operate for the SME in polymers. Amorphous SMP such as poly(methyl methacrylate) on heating above its glass transition temperature (Tg), micro-Brownian motion enables the polymer to return to its original shape. In another mechanism, one of two segments/domains in a polymer, one is always elastic (elastic component), while the other is able to significantly alter its stiffness, depending on whether the heat is applied (transition component). PU, which has a typical hard/soft-segment structure, is a good example for this type of mechanism. Yet another mechanism is based on the polymer itself as both the elastic and the transition components. Mostly, it is desirable to combine these mechanisms together to achieve optimized shape recovery temperature and higher recovery stress.16–18

One of the most interesting recent developments is the multiple SME, in which a polymer is able to recover its original shape through one or more intermediate shapes.19,20 It has been proved that the multiple SME or at least triple SME (i.e. there is only one intermediate shape between the temporary shape and original shape) can always be realized by programming.21

In some polymers, there are more than two transitions upon heating, for example one is the glass transition and the other is melting. Upon heating to just above Tg, shape recovery is only partial. However, upon further heating to around the melting temperature, full recovery can be achieved. The hybrid properties of SMP are reported, which has both the cooling-responsive SME and water-responsive SME. The hybrid is designed based on the concept of shape memory hybrid and is made of a plastic sponge (as elastic component) filled with Poloxamer 407 gel (as transition component).22 These smart materials are the basis of a large number of systems for potential applications in packaging, electronics, medicine, transportation, construction and aerospace.

Thermoset SMPs have scarcely been studied. There are a few reports on PUs,23–25 epoxies,26,27 cyanate esters,28–30 etc. A very recent review consolidates reports on shape memory epoxies.31 Elastic memory composites (EMCs) are similar to the traditional high-performance fiber-reinforced composites except for the use of an SMP as matrix that enables achievement of extraordinary packaging strains without damage.32–34 For self-deployable space structural applications, thermoset SMPs have several advantages over their thermoplast counterparts.

The bismaleimide (BMI) systems dominate over the other polymer matrices primarily due to their resistance and ability to withstand high stress at high temperatures at which typical phenolics and epoxies as well as most high-performance plastics are unstable.35 However, their processability and fracture toughness are not promising. To overcome this, they are coreacted with allyl derivatives whereby the curing occurs via Alder-Ene reaction.36–39 Very few studies have been reported on SMPs based on BMI resins. A series of SMPs, synthesized from 4-4′-bismaleimidodiphenylmethane, an extended chain aliphatic diamine and a diisocyanate, have been reported as high-temperature SMPs with tailorable transition temperatures for use in reconfigurable aerospace structures.40 Another study reports linear polyaspartimide-polyurea-based polymers utilizing 4-4-bismaleimidodiphenylmethane and an aliphatic diamine with some shape memory properties.41 The shape memory thermoset polymers prepared by copolymerizing of maleimide-based monomer and a vinyl compounds were reported to possess transition temperature of resin 150–270°C.42

The present article is the first ever report on the synthesis of BMI–diallyl phenol polymer system with shape memory properties. The matrix consists of o,o′-diallylbisphenol A (DABA) cured by 2,2-bis 4[(4-maleimidophenoxy)phenyl]propane (BMIP). For conferring SME, a bismaleimide-end-capped poly(tetramethyleneoxide) (BMI-PTMO) was coreacted with the BMI–allyl phenol resin system. This article gives the details of synthesis, processing and shape memory properties of their composites.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Poly(tetramethyleneoxide) (PTMO) with an average molecular weight of Mn = 2000 g mol−1 was supplied by Aldrich Chemicals (St. Louis, MO, USA). Maleic anhydride (CDH Chemicals, Mumbai, India) was purified by sublimation. BMIP and DABA were procured from ABR Organics (Hyderabad, India). Triethylamine (TEA), tetrahydrofuran (THF), ethyl methyl ketone and chloroform (all supplied by SRL Chemicals, Mumbai, India) were purified by distillation. Thionyl chloride (SOCl2) was supplied by Loba Chemie Chemicals (Mumbai, India). Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) and sodium sulfate (Na2SO4) were purchased from Nice Chemicals (Cochin, India). PTMO was dried in flash evaporator at 80°C for 5 h before use. Carbon cloth T-300 (eight harness satin weave, thickness ∼0.33 mm) was purchased from Torray (Tokyo, Japan).

sec.title: Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy
sec.p: FTIR spectra were recorded on a spectrum GXA model (Perkin-Elmer, MA, USA) in the range of 4000–550 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1.

sec.title: 13C nuclear magnetic resonance (13C NMR)
sec.p: 13C NMR spectra were recorded with a Bruker Avance NMR spectrometer (300 MHz) (Bruker UK Ltd., Coventry, UK) in deuterated chloroform.

sec.title: Size exclusion chromatography
sec.p: The size exclusion chromatographic analysis was carried out with Waters Alliance 2690 (Waters Corp., MA, USA) separation module in conjunction with Waters 410 differential refractive index (RI) detectors and ultraviolet (UV) detectors. The columns were Waters HR1 and HR2 Styragel columns.

sec.title: Differential scanning calorimetry
sec.p: Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetric analyses were carried out using a Mettler DSC Q20 (Mettler-Toledo, LLC, OH, USA). For DSC analysis, the samples were heated from room temperature to 300°C at a heating rate of 5°C min−1 in N2 atmosphere.

sec.title: Flexural properties
sec.p: Flexural strength was determined at room temperature by a three-point bending testing as per the standard ASTM D790 using a UTM (Instron Model 5569 (Instron Industrial Products, PA, USA)).

sec.title: Dynamic mechanical thermal analysis
sec.p: Dynamic mechanical properties were determined using TA instruments DMA Q800 (TA Instruments, DE, USA) in the three-point bending mode at a frequency of 1 Hz and a heating rate of 3°C min−1.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p: The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis was performed by Philips XL-30 instrument (Philips XL-30, Lancashire, UK). The operation voltage of the SEM was 10 kV with different magnification at ambient temperature.

sec.title: Rheological analysis
sec.p: Rheological characterization was done with a Reologica Stresstech Rheometer, model Reologica Viscotech QC (Reologica Viscotech QC, NJ, USA) using 20 mm parallel plate assembly in oscillation mode at a frequency of 1 Hz and controlled strain of 1%. The gap between the plates was maintained at 0.7 mm. The samples were loaded onto the plates at 50°C. Analysis was done by measuring the dynamic modulus (G′) at different time intervals at constant temperature.

sec.title: Bending test for shape memory properties
sec.p:
A straight rectangular strip of polymer composite of size 120 × 15 × 1 mm3 was used for the test at room temperature (28 ± 1°C). The polymer was heated to a temperature Ttrans + 20°C and deformed to an angle (θmax). Then the deformed polymer was cooled ∼Ttrans − 20°C to fix the deformation, and the resultant deformation was measured by angle (θfix). Then the deformed polymer was reheated (to Ttrans + 20) and the residual angle (θfinal) was recorded28 as schematically shown in Figure 1. sec.title: Synthesis of BMI-PTMO
sec.p: 4-Aminobenzoic acid was reacted with maleic anhydride and the resulting amic acid was imidized to give maleimidobenzoic acid (MBA) as per a reported procedure.43 It was characterized by FTIR, chemical analysis (acid value) and CHN analysis.44 MBA was converted into maleimidobenzoyl chloride by refluxing it with SOCl2. The excess SOCl2 was removed by distillation. PTMO was dissolved in THF-containing TEA, and this solution was added to maleimidobenzoyl chloride in THF medium to get BMI-PTMO. After completion of reaction (3 h), the solvent was removed by distillation and the resultant viscous fluid was poured into CHCl3. The filtrate was washed several times with 5% NaHCO3 solution and then with water. The CHCl3 solution was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 for 1 day, filtered and the solvent was removed in a flash evaporator at 50°C for 6 h. The resultant resin was characterized by FTIR, 13C and size exclusion chromatography (SEC). Estimation of ester value was done by chemical analysis.

sec.title: Preparation of EMC using carbon fabrics
sec.p: The BMI-PTMO, BMIP and DABA were coreacted. For this, the resin mixture was dissolved in methyl ethyl ketone and carbon prepregs were prepared by dipping the carbon fabric in the resin solution. After drying in air overnight, these prepregs were stacked and molded in a hydraulic press. The cure optimization study was done by DSC, Rheology and FTIR. EMCs were prepared by varying compositions, maintaining resin/fabric ratio (50:50 by weight) for all compositions. The molar ratio of allyl and maleimide groups was fixed as 1.2:1 and the three compositions containing varying BMI-PTMO content were prepared (Table 1).35 BMI-PTMO was presumed to have a molecular weight of 2430 g mol−1 (based on the molecular weight of PTMO) for the calculation of stoichiometry.

sec.title: Synthesis and characterization of BMI-PTMO
sec.p: The method of synthesis of BMI-PTMO is illustrated in Figure 2. The product was characterized by FTIR (Figure 3), 13C NMR (Figure 4) and chemical analyses. Characteristic peaks were observed at 1722 cm−1 corresponding to C=O stretching of ester group along with that of maleimide. The 13C NMR spectrum of BMI-PTMO shows signals at 26 ppm (–CH2–), 65 ppm (–CH2–O–C=O), 70 ppm (–OCH2–), 122, 128 and 131 ppm (aromatic carbon), 132 ppm (maleimide –C=C–), 165 ppm (maleimide >C=O) and 167 ppm (ester C=O). The ester value of BMI-PTMO (45 mg KOH g−1) conformed nearly to the theoretical value (46.1 mg KOH g−1). Figure 5 presents the SEC spectra of BMI-PTMO with RI and UV detectors. PTMO is insensitive to UV detector because it does not contain any chromophoric groups. In BMI-PTMO, endcapping is done with the UV-sensitive maleimide group. A comparison of SEC profiles by both RI and UV detector technique shows that all the polymer chains are end-capped with maleimide group. As expected, the end-capped polymer shows an increase in molecular weight and the low-molecular-weight fraction showed apparent increase in concentration because of increased concentration of maleimido groups in low molar mass of PTMO.

sec.title: Cure characterization of BMIP/DABA/BMI-PTMO system
sec.p: The cure characterization of the blend was done by DSC, FTIR and rheology. DSC (Figure 6) shows that the cure starts at 125°C through Alder–Ene reaction and spreads over a wide temperature with a peak at 250°C. The Alder–Ene reaction is known to proceed by an Ene reaction setting at 100–140°C followed by the Diels–Alder reaction at higher temperature.35 Although DSC showed a higher temperature for cure, under isothermal condition, a moderate temperature of 200°C was chosen as the ultimate cure temperature. Previous studies have shown that at higher cure temperature of 250°C, there is risk for thermal degradation of PTMO chains that are not integrated to the network.28 The cure schedule consists of four stages: 120°C, 1/2 h; 150°C, 1 h; 180°C, 1 h and 200°C, 5 h. Completion of cure reaction of the allyl and maleimide groups was confirmed by the absence of the peaks corresponding to allyl group at 1638 cm−1 and 996 cm−1 and of maleimide =C–H group at 828 cm−1 in the cured resin (Figure 7). Figure 8 shows the isothermal rheogram showing the cure profile of PTBMI-2 at 200°C. The storage modulus (G′) attains maximum and follows a plateau after 5 h, which is indicative of cure completion. Same cure schedule was followed for the preparation of EMCs too. NMR data could not be generated as the resin immediately becomes insoluble as the curing is initiated. The similar reaction mechanism of BMIP and DABA involving the BMI-PTMO is postulated in Figure 9. The proposed Figure 9 is based on the extrapolation of the established mechanism of Alder–Ene reaction to the present system.35

sec.title: Mechanical and dynamic mechanical properties
sec.p: Table 1 compiles the flexural strength and modulus of the various BMIP/DABA/BMI-PTMO systems. The flexural strength and modulus decrease with increase in the concentration of PTMO, implying that the PTMO provides the system more flexibility which also helps improve its shape memory properties (see later). The decrease in flexural strength is due to the incorporation of PTMO segments in the matrix that decreases the effective cross-link density of BMI–allyl system by matrix dilution and by plasticizing the network. The incorporation of PTMO segments (through BMI-PTMO) in the matrix decreases the effective cross-link density of BMI–allyl system by matrix dilution and by plasticizing the network because the BMI-PTMO contains the long aliphatic chain and end functionalized with maleimide group. During polymerization, these maleimide groups react with diallyl bisphenol A to form a cross-linked network. Due to the larger spacing of PTMO segments in the above cross-linked network, the effective cross-link density decreases and the molecules become easily mobile. The mobility is caused by the flexible ether linkage. Thus, if the concentration of PTMO segments is increased, the cross-link density of the matrix gets reduced due to the matrix dilution and plasticizing effect (Biju et al., Communicated). It has also been observed in our previous studies that increase in PTMO decreases the transition temperature of the matrix.

Viscoelastic properties of the samples (Table 2) were investigated by DMA in the three-point bending mode. Figures 10 and 11 indicate the storage modulus and loss tangent (tan δ) as a function of temperature for all the compositions. The temperature at the maximum value of tan δ indicates the transition temperature (Ttrans). A high glassy state modulus (Eg) provides the materials of high shape fixity. High glassy modulus is an indicative of high cohesive energy (mostly highly cross-linked) which leads to minimized propensity for creep-related shape change. Similarly, a decreasing trend in storage modulus and tan δ means that PTMO backbone helps increase the flexibility of the BMI–allyl phenol network. This is another proof that BMI-PTMO is integrated into the matrix by the way of coreaction of the maleimide end groups with the BMI systems. The storage modulus and tan δ temperature decrease with increase in the PTMO content. The modulus ratio (Eg/Er) was taken as (ETtrans−20′/ETtrans+20′), where ETtrans−20′/ETtrans+20′ stand for the storage modulus at temperature Ttrans − 20 and Ttrans + 20, respectively. This ratio is an index of shape recoverability and shows an increase in the PTMO content in the network. At high PTMO concentration, the Ttrans becomes more diffused. This is likely to arise from the uneven distribution of PTMO in the BMI matrix (microdomains of varying compositions may be coexisting). A sharp transition temperature is desirable for the application of the system for related application. DMA provided the Ttrans, which is defined as the transition temperature at which the shape recovery occurs. In this study, Ttrans is considered as the peak maximum temperature of tan δ in DMA of the composites. Thus, the estimated Ttrans of three EMCs named as PTBMI-1, PTBMI-2 and PTBMI-3 are 221.7, 180.8 and 140.5°C, respectively.

sec.title: SEM analysis
sec.p: Morphology of BMI–allyl phenol composites was studied using freshly fractured surfaces. Typical SEM micrographs are shown in Figure 12(a) and (b) of which samples failed in flexural test. Interphases of the composites clearly showed that the fiber wetting is poor in the case of PTBMI-1 (Figure 12(a)) because fiber surfaces are clearly visible. The SEM image of PTBMI-3 (Figure 12(b)) shows better wetting and indicates good packing than PTBMI-1. An increase in the concentration of PTMO segments helps increase the fiber wetting and results in good composites, although the flexural strength decreases due to flexibilization of the resin by PTMO.

caption.p: SEM images of the fracture surface of (a) PTBMI-1 and (b) PTBMI-3. SEM: scanning electron microscopy.

sec.title: Shape memory test (bending test)
sec.p: Qualitatively, the shape memory behavior was estimated by bending test between the temperatures Ttrans + 20°C and Ttrans − 20°C. Ttrans is taken as the temperature of maximum tan δ – temperature graph. The original (permanent) rectangular shape was heated at Ttrans + 20°C and the sample was deformed into U shape. Upon cooling under load, these deformed temporary shapes got fixed. On reheating above Ttrans + 20°C, the sample recovered its original rectangular shape. The recovered shape was nearly indistinguishable from the original shape, confirming the excellent shape fixity and recovery.

Variation in recovery time for composites of different resin compositions is given in Table 2. Shape recovery data are the average of three experiments (not the results of cyclic tests). The recovery time decreased with PTMO content, PTMO causing an increase in Eg/Er ratio. This is depicted in Figure 13. The extent of shape recovery was a direct function of the concentration of PTMO (Table 2). Shape recovery increases and recovery time decreases with increase in PTMO content. The reason is that highly cross-linked structures have strong constraining force on their segments, which need large free volume and more energy, necessitating higher temperature to accomplish shape recovery.45 All systems in the present case show shape retention (fixity) of ∼94%. The transition temperature and shape memory properties could be tuned by the composition of the blend. For application such as space deployment system and hinges, a slow recovery is recommended to avoid damage to the structure arising otherwise from sudden deployment. Thus, depending on the application, an appropriate composition can be chosen. The shape recovery of the composite (PTBMI-3) at different time intervals at 160°C was demonstrated experimentally (Figure 14). Demonstration was done by processing a rectangular strip of size 120 × 15 × 1 mm3. It was heated at 160°C and distorted and frozen in an ice bath. When the deformed composite was heated to 160°C, the original shape was recovered. The present system has comparable shape recovery to epoxy,26,27 PU,23–25 cyanate ester,28–30 etc. It has the advantage of higher Ttrans than the reported system. A higher Ttrans ensures minimal dimensional changes in the hibernated state.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: An SMP based on BMI–allyl phenol system is reported for the first time. EMCs possessing high transition temperatures (140–220°C) with varying shape memory characteristics were derived from BMI–allyl phenol–PTMO system reinforced with carbon fabric. Transition temperature and flexural strength decreased with increase in the concentration of SMP. Increasing PTMO concentration is conducive for increasing shape recovery with a concomitant decrease in recovery time. The composites have required strength and shape memory properties for possible use in the development of temperature responsive, self-deployable systems with good shape fixity. The high Ttrans helps retain the locked shape at ambient conditions.
